title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a fully refundable Child Tax Credit under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit allows for a specified amount for qualifying children based on their age, with a limitation on the total credit amount. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a fully refundable Child Tax Credit under section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding certain threshold amounts. The Child Tax Credit amount is based on the taxpayer's marital status and the number of qualifying children. The applicable amount is determined by dividing the credit amount by $20 multiplied by the total number of qualifying children. Marital status is determined under section 7703. The Child Tax Credit amount is calculated based on the taxpayer's marital status and the number of qualifying children. A qualifying child is defined as a dependent under 19 years of age, with exceptions for certain non-citizens. The $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) will be adjusted for inflation after 2017. After 2017, the $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) will be increased based on the cost of living adjustment for that year. Any increase not a multiple of $50 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Taxpayers must include the name and taxpayer identification number of qualifying children to claim the credit. Taxpayers must include the name and taxpayer identification number of qualifying children on the tax return to claim the credit. No credit will be allowed if the taxpayer's identification number was issued after the due date for filing the return. The credit is not allowable for a taxable year covering less than 12 months, except in the case of a taxpayer's death. Restrictions apply to taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in a prior year. Restrictions on taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in prior years include disallowance of the credit for a period of 10 taxable years after a final determination of fraud, and for 2 taxable years after a final determination of reckless claims. The taxpayer's claim of credit under this section may be denied for reckless or intentional disregard of rules and regulations, but not fraud. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in prior years must provide information to demonstrate eligibility for the credit in subsequent years. The taxpayer's claim of credit under this section may be denied for reckless or intentional disregard of rules and regulations, but not fraud. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in prior years must provide information to demonstrate eligibility for such credit. The amount of the credit allowed for any taxable year shall be reduced by the aggregate amount of any advance payments of the credit. If excess advance payments are made, the tax imposed for that year will be increased by the amount of the excess. "SEC. 7527A. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CHILD TAX CREDIT." The Secretary will establish a program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit within a year of enactment. Payments will be limited to avoid exceeding the total credit amount for each taxpayer. The program for advance monthly child tax credit payments will apply limitations to avoid exceeding the total credit amount for each taxpayer, as determined by the Secretary. The program will also make efforts to apply the threshold amount limitation of section 36C(b) to the payments made under the program. The table of sections for chapter 77 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new item for the Child tax credit under section 36C. Section 7527A allows for advance payment of child tax credit. Various sections of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to update references and rules related to taxes and child tax credit eligibility. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to update references and rules related to taxes and child tax credit eligibility. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016, including changes to sections 6211, 6213, and 1324.
